### Fourier Transform and Diffraction

In the context of wave optics, the diffraction pattern observed in the far field (Fraunhofer diffraction) can be understood as the Fourier transform of the aperture function. For a single slit, the aperture function is a rectangular function.

### Aperture Function of a Slit

Consider a single slit of width $b$ centered at $x = 0$. The aperture function $A(x)$ can be described as:

$$
A(x) = \begin{cases}
1 & \text{if } -\frac{b}{2} \leq x \leq \frac{b}{2} \\
0 & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}
$$

This is a rectangular function, often denoted as $\text{rect}\left(\frac{x}{b}\right)$.

### Fourier Transform of the Aperture Function

The Fourier transform of the aperture function $A(x)$ gives us the amplitude distribution in the far field. The Fourier transform $\mathcal{F}\{A(x)\}$ is defined as:

$$
\mathcal{F}\{A(x)\} = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} A(x) e^{-i 2 \pi f x} \, dx
$$

For the rectangular function $A(x) = \text{rect}\left(\frac{x}{b}\right)$, the Fourier transform is:

$$
\mathcal{F}\left\{\text{rect}\left(\frac{x}{b}\right)\right\} = \int_{-\frac{b}{2}}^{\frac{b}{2}} e^{-i 2 \pi f x} \, dx
$$

### Evaluating the Integral

Let's evaluate the integral:

$$
\mathcal{F}\left\{\text{rect}\left(\frac{x}{b}\right)\right\} = \int_{-\frac{b}{2}}^{\frac{b}{2}} e^{-i 2 \pi f x} \, dx
$$

This integral can be solved as follows:

$$
\mathcal{F}\left\{\text{rect}\left(\frac{x}{b}\right)\right\} = \left[ \frac{e^{-i 2 \pi f x}}{-i 2 \pi f} \right]_{-\frac{b}{2}}^{\frac{b}{2}}
$$

Substituting the limits:

$$
\mathcal{F}\left\{\text{rect}\left(\frac{x}{b}\right)\right\} = \frac{1}{-i 2 \pi f} \left( e^{-i 2 \pi f \frac{b}{2}} - e^{i 2 \pi f \frac{b}{2}} \right)
$$

Using Euler's formula $e^{i \theta} - e^{-i \theta} = 2i \sin(\theta)$:

$$
\mathcal{F}\left\{\text{rect}\left(\frac{x}{b}\right)\right\} = \frac{1}{-i 2 \pi f} \cdot (-2i \sin(\pi f b))
$$

Simplifying:

$$
\mathcal{F}\left\{\text{rect}\left(\frac{x}{b}\right)\right\} = \frac{2 \sin(\pi f b)}{2 \pi f} = \frac{\sin(\pi f b)}{\pi f}
$$

### Sinc Function

The result can be expressed in terms of the sinc function. The sinc function is defined as:

$$
\text{sinc}(x) = \frac{\sin(\pi x)}{\pi x}
$$

Therefore, the Fourier transform of the rectangular aperture function is:

$$
\mathcal{F}\left\{\text{rect}\left(\frac{x}{b}\right)\right\} = b \cdot \text{sinc}(b f)
$$

:::
